head.title: Coproduction of Value-Added Lube Base Oil and Green Diesel from Natural Triglycerides via a Simple Two-Step Process | Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research

meta.content: Coproduction of Value-Added Lube Base Oil and Green Diesel from Natural Triglycerides via a Simple Two-Step Process

A versatile process for coproducing green diesel and value-added lube base oil from natural triglycerides (e.g., vegetable oil, waste cooking oil, and microalgal oil) was developed. The two-step reaction process comprises (i) thermal oligomerization of triglycerides via Diels–Alder and/or radical-mediated addition of the C═C bonds within the fatty acid units and (ii) catalytic deoxygenation of the oligomerized triglycerides via hydro-upgrading. Different triglyceride sources, that is, palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil, were investigated as the starting feedstock. Thermal oligomerization of the triglycerides at 300 °C proceeded at the expense of the C═C bonds within the unsaturated fatty acid units. Thus, the degree of triglyceride oligomerization was enhanced when the reactant triglycerides contained more unsaturated fatty acid units (palm oil < soybean oil < soybean + linseed oil < linseed oil). The oligomerized triglycerides were subsequently deoxygenated over a Pt-MoOx/TiO2 catalyst, which converted the oligomerized and monomeric fatty acid units into lube base oil (C30–C54) and green diesel (C15–C18) fractions, respectively. The produced lube base oils were completely saturated with very high viscosity indexes (>120) and a nondetectable sulfur content, which could meet the specifications of high-quality group III lube base oil.

div.p:
A versatile process for coproducing green diesel and value-added lube base oil from natural triglycerides (e.g., vegetable oil, waste cooking oil, and microalgal oil) was developed. The two-step reaction process comprises (i) thermal oligomerization of triglycerides via Diels–Alder and/or radical-mediated addition of the C═C bonds within the fatty acid units and (ii) catalytic deoxygenation of the oligomerized triglycerides via hydro-upgrading. Different triglyceride sources, that is, palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil, were investigated as the starting feedstock. Thermal oligomerization of the triglycerides at 300 °C proceeded at the expense of the C═C bonds within the unsaturated fatty acid units. Thus, the degree of triglyceride oligomerization was enhanced when the reactant triglycerides contained more unsaturated fatty acid units (palm oil < soybean oil < soybean + linseed oil < linseed oil). The oligomerized triglycerides were subsequently deoxygenated over a Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
catalyst, which converted the oligomerized and monomeric fatty acid units into lube base oil (C
30
–C
54
) and green diesel (C
15
–C
18
) fractions, respectively. The produced lube base oils were completely saturated with very high viscosity indexes (>120) and a nondetectable sulfur content, which could meet the specifications of high-quality group III lube base oil.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The depletion of fossil sources and escalating environmental issues are driving the need to produce fuels and chemicals from renewable biomass sources.
(1−4)
Among the various biomass feedstocks, triglycerides (e.g., vegetable oil, waste cooking oil, and microalgal oil), the esters of three fatty acids (C
14
–C
22
), and one glycerol are particularly promising for fuel production because of their relatively low oxygen content.
(3,4)
Therefore, triglycerides have often been converted to biodiesel (fatty acid alkyl esters) via transesterification with short chain alcohols (e.g., methanol and ethanol).
(5,6)
Because oxygen-containing biodiesel still suffers from limited compatibility with internal combustion engines, low energy density, poor cold flow properties, and oxidative instability,
(6,7)
catalytic deoxygenation processes for producing oxygen-free paraffinic diesel (“green diesel”) have also been widely investigated.
(8−12)
The resultant paraffins can be further hydrocracked to produce bio-jet fuel.
(13,14)
Despite extensive efforts to produce transportation fuels from triglycerides, attempts at producing other value-added chemicals are relatively scarce. The coproduction of value-added chemicals along with biofuels is highly important for improving the overall economics and life-cycle assessments of biorefineries.
(15,16)

Lube base oil, used for manufacturing lubricating greases, motor oil, and metal processing fluids, is one potential value-added product that can be produced from triglycerides. Natural triglycerides themselves may afford excellent lubrication performance, with a high viscosity index and anticorrosion properties.
(17,18)
Unfortunately, pristine triglycerides suffer from low oxidative stability because of the presence of ester and C═C functional groups.
(19−21)
These significant drawbacks of pristine triglycerides as lube base oils may be overcome by developing new catalytic processes that can convert the triglycerides into oxygen-free branched paraffins with carbon number distributions in the C
20
–C
70
range. One proposed method of producing oxygen-free lube base oil from triglycerides involves a series of complex reactions consisting of (i) hydrolysis of triglycerides into fatty acids, (ii) hydrogenation (saturation) of fatty acids, (iii) dimerization of fatty acids via ketonization, (iv) catalytic deoxygenation, and (v) hydroisomerization.
(22−24)

In the present work, we demonstrate a much simpler process (
Scheme 1
) that enables the coproduction of high-quality lube base oil (C
30
–C
54
) along with green diesel (C
15
–C
18
). The process consists of only two reaction steps: (i) thermal oligomerization of natural triglycerides using the C═C bonds within the unsaturated fatty acid chains and (ii) subsequent catalytic deoxygenation via hydro-upgrading. In our previous studies,
(25)
we showed that the thermal oligomerization of triglycerides (step i) is the main reason for the catalyst fouling and deactivation during the triglyceride hydroupgrading. In the present work, we deliberately oligomerized the triglycerides before catalytic deoxygenation, in order to increase the molecular size of final deoxygenated hydrocarbon products, which would be suitable as lube-base oil (C
30
–C
54
). The newly developed process allows control of the yield and properties of the product lube base oil by varying the initial fatty acid compositions of the reactant triglycerides. The produced lube base oils have a very high viscosity index (>120), saturation level (>99%), and undetectable sulfur content, which can meet the specifications of group III lube base oil.
Scheme 1. Schematic Process Diagram for the Coproduction of Green Diesel and Lube Base Oil

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 2.1. Analysis of Fatty Acid Composition of Triglycerides
div.div:
Palm oil (Aldrich), soybean oil (Aldrich), linseed oil (Daejung), and a 1:1 mixture of soybean and linseed oil were used as the triglyceride sources for coproducing green diesel and lube base oil. The fatty acid compositions of these triglycerides were analyzed using gas chromatography (GC) after transesterification with methanol.
(26)
For transesterification, 1.0 g of each triglyceride was reacted with 0.25 g of methanol (methanol/triglyceride ratio ∼ 6) at 65 °C for 1 h using 1 wt % NaOH as a catalyst. The upper-phase products (i.e., fatty acid methyl esters) and
n
-dodecane (TCI) as an external standard were dissolved in chloroform and analyzed using a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and HP-5 column (Agilent, 30 m × 0.32 mm).

Thermal oligomerization of the triglycerides (palm oil, soybean oil, linseed oil, and 1:1 mixture of soybean and linseed oil) was carried out in a stainless-steel autoclave having an internal volume of 200 mL. Typically, 100 g of triglyceride was loaded and the headspace was filled with 1 bar N
2
. Thermal oligomerization was carried out at 300 °C under stirring (500 rpm) for 4 h.

Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
, Pt/TiO
2
, and Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
were prepared as catalysts for the deoxygenation reaction. Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
and Pt/TiO
2
were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of γ-Al
2
O
3
(Strem) and TiO
2
(P25, Aldrich) with an aqueous solution of Pt(NH
3
)
4
(NO
3
)
2
(Aldrich). After drying at 100 °C, the sample was calcined at 400 °C (ramp: 2 °C min
–1
) in dry air for 4 h and reduced under H
2
at 300 °C (ramp: 2 °C min
–1
) for 4 h. The nominal loading of Pt was fixed at 3 wt %. Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
was prepared by a sequential wet impregnation method.
(27)
Titanium dioxide (TiO
2
) was first impregnated with an aqueous solution of (NH
4
)

Mo

·4H
2
O (Aldrich). After drying at 100 °C, the sample was calcined at 400 °C (ramp: 2 °C min
–1
) in dry air for 4 h. The sample was then further impregnated with an aqueous solution of Pt(NH
3
)
4
(NO
3
)
2
. After drying at 100 °C, the sample was reduced under H
2
at 300 °C (ramp: 2 °C min
–1
) for 4 h. The nominal loadings of both Mo and Pt were fixed at 3 wt %.

Metal (Pt and Mo) contents of the catalysts were analyzed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES 720, Agilent). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images of the catalysts were collected using a Talos F200X microscope operating at 200 kV. The samples were mounted on a carbon-coated Cu grid (300 mesh) using ethanol dispersion. To determine the Pt particle size distributions, more than 200 crystallites were counted. The surface-area-weighted mean particle diameter was calculated using the following equation
(28)

div.h3: 2.4. Catalytic Deoxygenation of Pristine and Oligomerized Triglycerides
div.div:
Catalytic deoxygenation was carried out in a stainless-steel autoclave (internal volume of 200 mL). Typically, 5.0 g of the pristine or thermally oligomerized triglycerides, 30 g of
n
-octane as a solvent, and 0.24 g of the catalysts were loaded into the autoclave. After filling the headspace with 50 bar H
2
, the reaction was carried out at 320 °C under stirring (500 rpm) for 4 h. After the reaction, the liquid products and catalysts were separated by filtration and
n
-octane was removed using a rotary evaporator.

The liquid products collected after the thermal oligomerization and catalytic deoxygenation steps were analyzed by combining several complementary techniques. The molecular size distributions were analyzed by gel permeation chromatography (GPC) using an Agilent 1260 Infinity equipped with two PLgel 5 μm MIXED-C columns (Agilent, 300 mm × 7.5 mm) and a refractive index detector. The deoxygenated products were characterized by analyzing the boiling point (bp) distributions via simulated distillation (SIMDIS) using an AC SIMDIS analyzer (Agilent 7890 GC) according to the ASTM D7500 method. The products with bp below that of
n
-C
18
(317 °C) were assigned as C
15
–C
18
paraffins, which were produced by the deoxygenation of monomeric fatty acids. The products with bp between 317 and 497 °C (bp of
n
-C
36
) were assigned as C
30
–C
36
(i.e., deoxygenated products of dimeric fatty acids), while those with bp between 497 and 596 °C (bp of
n
-C
54
) were assigned as C
45
–C
54
(i.e., deoxygenated products of trimeric fatty acids). The products having a bp exceeding 596 °C were assigned as >C
54
paraffins. Distribution of C
15
–C
18
paraffin products were quantitatively analyzed using
n
-dodecane as an external standard by GC equipped with an FID and a DB-5 column (Agilent, 30 m × 0.25 mm). C, H, and O contents were determined using an elemental analyzer (Thermo Scientific, FLASH 2000).
13
C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy was carried out after dissolving the products in CDCl
3
(Aldrich). The NMR spectra were recorded using an Agilent DD2 400 MHz NMR instrument with 1.3 s acquisition time, 25 s relaxation delay, and 256 transients. All spectra used for quantitative analysis were recorded using inverse-gated proton decoupling to avoid the nuclear Overhauser effect.

The residual amount of C═C bonds was quantified by determining the iodine value.
(29)
Typically, 0.1 g of the liquid products was dissolved in 20 mL of chloroform (Samchun). Thereafter, 25 mL of Wijs solution (Aldrich) was added and the mixture was stored in the dark for 1 h at room temperature. After the reaction, 30 mL of 0.1 N KI acetic acid solution was added, with subsequent addition of 100 mL of distilled water. The solution was titrated with 0.1 M of sodium thiosulfate aqueous solution until the yellow color disappeared. Subsequently, 2 mL of 1 wt % starch solution was added, and titration was continued until the blue color disappeared. A blank experiment without the sample was also carried out. The iodine value (grams of absorbed I
2
/100 g sample) was calculated using the following equation
(2)
where
B
is the titration volume of the blank (mL),
S
is the titration volume of the sample solution (mL),
C
is the molar concentration of the solution (mol L
–1
), 0.1269 indicates the amount of iodine (g) that reacts with 1 mL of 1 M sodium thiosulfate solution, and
m
oil
is the sample weight (g).

div.h3: 2.6. Separation and Analysis of Lube Base Oil
div.div:
To separate the green diesel and lube base oil fractions from the final deoxygenated products, short-path distillation was carried out using a thin-film evaporator.
(30)
The surface areas of the evaporator and the condenser were 180 and 70 cm
2
, respectively. For distillation, the deoxygenated oil was injected at a rate of 30 mL h
–1
; the rotation speed of the roller wiper was fixed at 400 rpm. The temperatures of the evaporator and condenser were fixed at 90 and 25 °C, respectively. The pressure within the distillation apparatus was maintained at 10
–3
mbar using an oil rotary vane pump equipped with a cold trap containing liquid N
2
. The distillate (green diesel) and residue (lube base oil) fractions were collected separately for further analysis. The kinematic viscosities at two temperatures (40 and 100 °C) were analyzed using the ASTM D445 protocol, and the viscosity index was calculated using the ASTM D2270 method. The sulfur content was analyzed using the ASTM D4294 method.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 3.1. Effects of Fatty Acid Composition on Triglyceride Oligomerization
div.div:
The fatty acid composition of palm oil, soybean oil, linseed oil, and the 1:1 mixture of soybean and linseed oil (denoted as “soy + lin”) is summarized in
Table
1
. The triglyceride sources mainly comprised C
16
and C
18
fatty acid units and contained fully saturated palmitic acid as the sole C
16
fatty acid. The triglyceride sources contained significantly different portions of saturated (stearic acid) and unsaturated (oleic acid, linoleic acid, and linolenic acid) C
18
fatty acids. The average number of C═C bonds per fatty acid unit (or degree of unsaturation) increased in the following order: palm oil (0.55) < soybean oil (1.33) < soy + lin (1.76) < linseed oil (2.18).
Table 1. Fatty Acid Composition of Triglyceride Sources

tr.td: avg # of C═C in a fatty acid

div.div:
The triglycerides were subjected to catalyst-free thermal oligomerization at 300 °C for 4 h in a stainless-steel autoclave. Thermal oligomerization induced no appreciable weight change of the liquid phase, regardless of the triglyceride source. The thermally oligomerized products are denoted as “
n
-TO,” where
n
indicates the initial triglyceride source (palm, soybean, soy + lin, and linseed). The molecular size distributions of the triglycerides before and after thermal oligomerization were analyzed using GPC (
Figure
1
). All the pristine triglycerides (
Figure
1
a) showed a single peak at the retention time of 16.4 min, which is consistent with the fact that all triglycerides have similar average molecular weights (
Table
1
). After oligomerization at 300 °C, additional peaks appeared at shorter retention times (15.8 and 15.5 min) at the expense of the major peak at 16.4 min (
Figure
1
b). The new peaks at 15.8 and 15.5 min were assigned to the dimerized and trimerized triglycerides, respectively. Notably, the decrease in the intensity of the major peak at 16.4 min and the development of new peaks at 15.8 and 15.5 min were more pronounced for the oils in the following order: palm oil < soybean oil < soy + lin < linseed oil. This result implies that thermal oligomerization was facilitated when the initial triglyceride sources contained more unsaturated fatty acid units or C═C bonds (
Table
1
).

div.p: Figure 1. GPC profiles of (a) pristine and (b) thermally oligomerized triglycerides.

div.div:
The
13
C NMR spectra of the triglycerides before and after thermal oligomerization are shown in
Figure
2
. The NMR peaks at 124–130 ppm could be assigned to the sp
2
carbons of the C═C bonds (β
i
) in the unsaturated fatty acid units of the triglycerides. The intensity of these peaks followed the order (
Figure
2
a): palm oil < soybean oil < soy + lin < linseed oil, which is consistent with the average number of C═C bonds per fatty acid unit in the triglyceride sources (
Table
1
). After thermal oligomerization (
Figure
2
b), the intensity of these peaks decreased drastically, indicating that thermal oligomerization occurred at the expense of the C═C bonds. The disappearance of the C═C bonds was also confirmed by the significantly decreased iodine values of the triglycerides after thermal oligomerization (
Table
2
). These results are consistent with earlier reports showing that the unsaturated fatty acid units of triglycerides can be oligomerized via Diels–Alder and/or radical-mediated addition (
Scheme 2
).
(31)
For the Diels–Alder reaction to occur, the C═C bonds in the polyunsaturated fatty acids (linoleic and linolenic acid) must migrate first to form cis-conjugated dienes.
(31,32)
The cis-conjugated dienes then react with another unsaturated fatty acid (oleic, linoleic, or linolenic acid) to form a cyclohexene-like ring. On the other hand, radical-mediated addition is initiated by the abstraction of hydrogen from the methylene between two C═C bonds (allylic position for both C═C bonds), which is highly active for radical formation.
(31,33)
The resultant radical can be added to the C═C bonds of other unsaturated fatty acids (oleic, linoleic, and linolenic acids). Both reactions consume the C═C bonds of the unsaturated fatty acid units to form additional C–C bonds between them. Notably, the
13
C NMR peaks at 71 (γ) and 64 ppm (δ) were preserved after thermal oligomerization, where these peaks can be assigned to the carbon atoms in the glyceride backbone. These results indicate that oligomerization of unsaturated fatty acid units occurred at the expense of C═C bonds, while the glyceride backbone of the triglycerides remained intact. The negligible decomposition of the glyceride backbone is consistent with the insubstantial change in the mass of the liquid phase after thermal oligomerization.

div.p:
Figure 2.
13
C NMR spectra of (a) pristine and (b) thermally oligomerized triglycerides.

div.div: Scheme 2. Possible Pathways for the Oligomerization of Triglycerides: (a) Diels–Alder Reaction and (b) Radical-Mediated Addition
Table 2. Iodine Values of Pristine and Oligomerized Triglycerides

We also investigated the effects of oligomerization temperatures other than 300 °C. Product analysis using GPC revealed that oligomerization at 250 °C (Figure S1a in
Supporting Information
) resulted in very limited oligomerization of triglycerides (i.e., the dimer peak at 15.8 min was not substantially developed). On the other hand, thermal oligomerization at 350 °C (Figure S1b in
Supporting Information
) showed peak tailing even below 15 min for soybean and linseed oils. This indicated the formation of polymers in addition to dimers and trimers of triglycerides. In addition, new peaks were observed at 16.8, 17.3, and 17.8 min, which could be assigned to dimer acids (C
35
–C
36
), monomeric fatty acids (C
16
–C
18
), and oxygen-free hydrocarbons, respectively (Figure S2 in
Supporting Information
). These species could be produced by thermal decomposition of the glyceride backbones of oligomerized/polymerized triglycerides. This result is consistent with the previous reports showing that triglycerides can be thermally decomposed into fatty acids, followed by subsequent deoxygenation at temperatures higher than 300 °C.
(34,35)
13
C NMR spectra of the products (Figure S3 in
Supporting Information
) showed that the peaks at 71 and 64 ppm (carbons in glyceride backbones) and the peak at 175 ppm (carbons in the carbonyl groups of esters) completely disappeared after the oligomerization at 350 °C. At the same time, a new peak at 183 ppm (carbons in the carbonyl groups of fatty acids) was developed (Figure S3 in
Supporting Information
), which indicated the complete decomposition of the glyceride backbone. These GPC and
13
C NMR results indicate that the oligomerization temperature of 350 °C is too high for retaining the glyceride backbone of triglycerides and suppressing excessive polymerization. In this regard, we propose 300 °C as the optimal temperature for triglyceride oligomerization.

div.h3: 3.2. Catalytic Deoxygenation of Pristine and Oligomerized Triglycerides
div.div:
To produce paraffinic green diesel and lube base oil, the pristine and thermally oligomerized triglycerides were catalytically deoxygenated at 320 °C for 4 h under 50 bar H
2
. All reactions were carried out in an autoclave at a sufficiently high stirring rate (500 rpm) to avoid mass transfer limitation (Figure S4 in
Supporting Information
). Three different catalysts, that is, Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
(3.1 wt % Pt), Pt/TiO
2
(2.9 wt % Pt), and Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
(2.7 wt % Pt/2.9 wt % Mo), were synthesized and compared in the reaction. In a recent study, Shimizu and colleagues reported that the Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
catalyst is superior to other types of Pt catalysts in the deoxygenation of esters and ketones.
(27)
They reported that Lewis acid sites on the surface of MoO
x
/TiO
2
can efficiently activate C═O groups, which can then readily react with activated hydrogen generated at the surface of the Pt catalyst. According to TEM investigation, Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
(
Figure
3
a) exhibited surface-area-weighted mean Pt cluster diameter (
d
TEM
) of 1.8 nm, which is comparable to those of Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
(2.1 nm, Figure S5a in
Supporting Information
) and Pt/TiO
2
(2.5 nm, Figure S5b in
Supporting Information
). Despite the similar Pt dispersions, the deoxygenation activity (i.e., removal of O atoms) of Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
was superior to those of Pt/γ-Al
2
O
3
and Pt/TiO
2
(
Figure
3
b) for both pristine and oligomerized linseed oils. In this regard, Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
was selected as a catalyst for later deoxygenation reactions.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) TEM image and particle size distribution of the Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
catalyst. (b) Oxygen contents of the pristine and thermally oligomerized linseed oils before and after the deoxygenation over various Pt catalysts (reaction conditions: 320 °C, 50 bar H
2
, 4 h).

div.div:
The deoxygenated products from the pristine triglycerides and thermally oligomerized triglycerides are denoted as “
n
-DO” and “
n
-TO-DO,” respectively, wherein
n
indicates the initial triglyceride source (palm, soybean, soy + lin, and linseed). After catalytic deoxygenation, the yield of liquid hydrocarbon products was consistently in the range of 81–84 wt % with respect to the initial weight of the pristine and oligomerized triglycerides. The liquid yields were slightly smaller than the theoretical yields (∼87 wt %) crudely calculated by assuming that the glyceride backbone was fully decomposed into light gaseous species (e.g., CO, CO
2
, and C
1
–C
3
hydrocarbons), while the deoxygenation of fatty acids proceeded solely via the hydrodeoxygenation pathway (removal of O as H
2
O). Elemental analysis revealed that the oxygen content of all the liquid products was negligible (<0.1 wt %), with H/C molar ratios of ∼2 (Table S1 in
Supporting Information
), indicating complete deoxygenation/hydrogenation of the triglycerides into saturated paraffins. Complete deoxygenation/hydrogenation was further confirmed by the
13
C NMR spectra (
Figure
4
), which showed only the peaks of sp
3
carbon species (R
3
C
H, R
2
C
H
2
, and R
C
H
3
) and the negligibly small iodine values (
Table
2
). In
13
C NMR spectra (
Figure
4
), the direct deoxygenated products of the pristine triglycerides (
n
-DO samples) did not show the peaks for tertiary carbon (R
3
C
H, 34–48 ppm), while the deoxygenated products of the thermally oligomerized triglycerides (
n
-TO-DO) showed such peaks. The detection of tertiary carbon atoms indicates the presence of branched paraffin structures. Such branched structures can only be formed by the oligomerization of unsaturated fatty acids and subsequent deoxygenation (
Scheme 1
) and are likely to be suitable as a component of lube base oil.

div.p:
Figure 4.
13
C NMR spectra of catalytically deoxygenated products from (a) pristine and (b) thermally oligomerized triglycerides.

div.div:
The GPC profiles of the deoxygenated products are shown in
Figure
5
. The deoxygenated products of the pristine triglycerides (
n
-DO samples) showed a dominant peak at 17.6 min (
Figure
5
a). The peak was assigned to the C
15
–C
18
paraffins produced by the deoxygenation of monomeric fatty acid units (Figure S6 in
Supporting Information
). Such paraffins can be considered as green diesel having very high cetane numbers (>55).
(9)
Detailed paraffin distributions in the C
15
–C
18
products were quantitatively analyzed using GC (
Table
3
). The most dominant species were
n
-C
16
and C
18
, which had the same carbon numbers with the major fatty acid components in the original triglycerides (
Table
1
). The result indicated that the major deoxygenation pathway is hydrodeoxygenation (removal of O as H
2
O) rather than decarboxylation (removal of O as CO
2
)/decarbonylation (removal of O as CO).
(27)
The GPC peak assigned to green diesel (17.6 min) was less intense for the deoxygenated products of the thermally oligomerized triglycerides (
n
-TO-DO). Instead, additional peaks at 17.1 and 16.7 min were clearly developed (
Figure
5
b), where these peaks can be assigned to the C
30
–C
36
and C
45
–C
54
paraffins produced by deoxygenation of the dimerized and trimerized fatty acid units (Figure S6 in
Supporting Information
), respectively. These new peaks became more intense when the initial triglyceride sources contained more unsaturated fatty acid units (palm oil < soybean oil < soy + lin < linseed oil). In the case of the linseed-TO-DO sample, appreciable peak tailing was observed even down to the retention time of 16 min (
Figure
5
b). This may indicate that paraffins even larger than C
54
(i.e., deoxygenated products of higher fatty acid oligomers than trimers) were also formed because of the very high content of C═C bonds in linseed oil (
Table
1
).

div.p: Figure 5. GPC profiles of the catalytically deoxygenated products from (a) pristine and (b) thermally oligomerized triglycerides.

div.div:

15
–C

Paraffins in Deoxygenated Oils

Simulated distillation (SIMDIS) was carried out to analyze the carbon number distributions of the deoxygenated products based on the boiling point (bp) distributions (
Figure
6
). The sum of the paraffin yields for the components larger than C
30
was considered as the yield of lube base oil. Consistent with the previous GPC results (
Figure
5
), the direct deoxygenation products of the pristine triglycerides (
n
-DO samples,
Figure
6
a) were predominantly composed of C
15
–C
18
paraffins (green diesel) and the yields of lube base oil-range paraffins were negligible (<3 wt %). In contrast, the deoxygenated products of the thermally oligomerized triglycerides (
n
-TO-DO samples,
Figure
6
b) contained significant amounts of lube base oil-range ≥C
30
paraffins in addition to C
15
–C
18
paraffins. As expected, the yields of ≥C
30
paraffins (lube base oil) gradually increased when the more unsaturated triglyceride sources (palm oil < soybean oil < soy + lin < linseed oil) were initially used. Within the lube base oil fractions, the portion of heavier hydrocarbons (≥C
45
) also increased in the same order.

div.p: Figure 6. Paraffin yields after catalytic deoxygenation of (a) pristine and (b) thermally oligomerized triglycerides.

div.div:
Reusability of the Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
catalyst was investigated in the deoxygenation of linseed-TO. Deoxygenation efficiency of Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
slightly decreased from 100 to 94% even after five repeated reaction cycles (
Figure
7
a). The result indicated only minor deactivation of the catalyst. ICP-OES analysis of the used catalyst after five reaction cycles indicated that Pt and Mo leaching was not detectable (used catalyst: 2.8 wt % Pt/2.7 wt % Mo, fresh catalyst: 2.7 wt % Pt/2.9 wt % Mo) within the accuracy level of the analysis technique. According to TEM analysis of the used catalyst (
Figure
7
b), surface-area-weighted mean cluster diameter (
d
TEM
) increased slightly (2.1 nm) compared to that of the fresh catalyst (1.8 nm). It is likely that the slight catalyst deactivation of the catalyst might be due to the minor sintering of Pt particles.

div.p:
Figure 7. (a) Reusability of the Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
catalyst in the deoxygenation of thermally oligomerized linseed oil. (b) TEM image and Pt particle size distribution of Pt-MoO

after 5 repeated reaction cycles.

div.h3: 3.3. Separation and Analysis of Fractionated Lube Base Oil
div.div:
To separate the lube base oil (>C
30
) from the green diesel (<C
30
), the deoxygenated products were subjected to short-path distillation using a thin-film evaporator (see
Experimental Section
). The lube base oil separated from “
n
-TO-DO” is denoted as “
n
-TO-DO-LB,” wherein
n
indicates the initial triglyceride source (palm, soybean, soy + lin, and linseed). The key physical properties of the separated lube base oil were analyzed, including the kinematic viscosity, viscosity index, saturate content, and sulfur content (
Table
4
). For comparison, typical specifications of lube base oils provided by the American Petroleum Institute (API) are also summarized in
Table
4
. The lube base oils (
n
-TO-DO-LB) produced by the present process had a very high viscosity index (>120), saturate content (>99%), and nondetectable sulfur content, which all satisfied the group III base oil specifications. It is noteworthy that group I lube base oil has been globally replaced by group III lube base oil having higher quality because of the demand of customers and enhanced environmental regulations.
(36)
The kinematic viscosity and viscosity index gradually increased in the following order: soybean-TO-DO-LB < soy + lin-TO-DO-LB < linseed-TO-DO-LB. Based on the results in
Figure
6
, it can be concluded that a higher content of heavier paraffins (≥C
45
) led to increased kinematic viscosity and a higher viscosity index of the lube base oil.
Table 4. Specifications of Produced Lube Base Oils and Conventional Lube Base Oils Provided by American Petroleum Institute (API)

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In the present work, we developed a versatile process for coproducing value-added lube base oil and green diesel from natural triglycerides. The process comprises only two reaction steps: (i) thermal oligomerization of triglycerides and (ii) catalytic deoxygenation of the oligomerized triglycerides via hydro-upgrading. The results show that the C═C bonds within the unsaturated fatty acid units of triglycerides can be oligomerized via Diels–Alder reaction and/or radical-mediated addition, even without a catalyst, at 300 °C. The degree of oligomerization increased when the initial triglycerides contained more unsaturated fatty acids (palm oil < soybean oil < soy + lin < linseed oil). The thermally oligomerized triglyceride sources were deoxygenated over a Pt-MoO
x
/TiO
2
catalyst under 50 bar H
2
, which could convert the oligomerized and monomeric fatty acid units into lube base oil (≥C
30
) and green diesel (C
15
–C
18
), respectively. This process enables control of the yields and properties of the lube base oil by varying the initial fatty acid composition of the triglycerides. The lube base oils produced from all sources had a very high viscosity index (>120), saturate content (>99%), and nondetectable sulfur content, making them suitable as high-quality group III lube base oil.

A review. This article is an up-to-date review of the literature available on the subject of liq. biofuels. In search of a suitable fuel alternative to fast depleting fossil fuel and oil reserves and in serious consideration of the environmental issues assocd. with the extensive use of fuels based on petrochems., research work is in progress worldwide. Researchers have been re-directing their interests in biomass based fuels, which currently seem to be the only logical alternative for sustainable development in the context of economical and environmental considerations. Renewable bioresources are available globally in the form of residual agricultural biomass and wastes, which can be transformed into liq. biofuels. However, the process of conversion, or chem. transformation, could be very expensive and not worth-while to use for an economical large-scale com. supply of biofuels. Hence, there is still need for much research to be done for an effective, economical and efficient conversion process. Therefore, this article is written as a broad overview of the subject, and includes information based on the research conducted globally by scientists according to their local socio-cultural and economic situations.

A review with 38 refs. Diesel fuels derived from triglycerides (vegetable oils/animal fats) present a promising alternative to substitute diesel fuels. Although triglycerides can fuel diesel engines, their high viscosities, low volatilities and poor cold flow properties have led to the investigation of various derivs. Fatty acid Me esters, known as biodiesel, derived from triglycerides by transesterification with methanol have received the most attention. The main advantages of using biodiesel are its renewability, better-quality exhaust gas emissions, its biodegradability and given that all the org. carbon present is photosynthetic in origin, it does not contribute to a rise in the level of carbon dioxide in the atm. and consequently to the greenhouse effect.

A review. Biodiesel is gaining more and more importance as an attractive fuel due to the depleting fossil fuel resources. Chem. biodiesel is monoalkyl esters of long chain fatty acids derived from renewable feed stock like vegetable oils and animal fats. It is produced by transesterification in which, oil or fat is reacted with a monohydric alc. in presence of a catalyst. The process of transesterification is affected by the mode of reaction condition, molar ratio of alc. to oil, type of alc., type and amt. of catalysts, reaction time and temp. and purity of reactants. In the present paper various methods of prepn. of biodiesel with different combination of oil and catalysts have been described. The tech. tools and processes for monitoring the transesterification reactions like TLC, GC, HPLC, GPC, 1H NMR and NIR have also been summarized. In addn., fuel properties and specifications provided by different countries are discussed.

A review. The search for alternatives to petroleum-based fuels has led to the development of fuels from various sources, including renewable feedstocks such as fats and oils. Several types of fuels can be derived from these triacylglycerol-contg. feedstocks. One of them is biodiesel, which is defined as the mono-alkyl esters of vegetable oils or animal fats. Biodiesel is produced by transesterifying the oil or fat with an alc. such as methanol under mild conditions in the presence of a base catalyst. Another kind of product that can be obtained from lipid feedstocks is a fuel whose compn. simulates that of petroleum-derived diesel fuel. This kind of fuel, probably best termed "renewable diesel", is produced from the fat or oil by a hydrodeoxygenation reaction at elevated temp. and pressure in the presence of a catalyst. This article discusses in a general and comparative fashion aspects such as fuel prodn. and energy balance, fuel properties, environmental effects including exhaust emissions and co-products. Among the questions that are addressed are if these fuels compete with or complement each other and what the effect of prodn. scale may be.

Microalgae oil can be nearly quant. hydrodeoxygenated to alkanes by cascade reactions on bifunctional catalysts based on Ni and an acidic zeolite. Ni catalyzes the hydrogenolysis of the fatty acid ester, the decarbonylation of aldehyde intermediates, as well as the hydrogenation of -COOH, -CHO and C=C double bonds in reactants and intermediates. The acid function catalyzes the dehydration of alc. intermediates and the hydroisomerization and hydrocracking of the alkane products. The knowledge of the individual reaction rates allows balancing these rates by adjusting the concn. of catalytically active sites to design tailored and stable catalysts for selectively converting crude microalgae oil to diesel-range alkanes. This approach opens new possibilities to produce sulfur-free high-grade green transportation fuels from microalgae on a large scale.

The Saskatchewan Research Council (SRC), in cooperation with Natural Resources Canada and Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, investigated the use of conventional refinery technol. to convert vegetable oils into a product resembling diesel fuel. SRC found that the use of a medium severity refinery hydroprocess yielded a product ('super cetane') in the diesel boiling range with a high cetane value (55-90). Preliminary engine testing by ORTECH has shown that the impact of the 'super cetane'/diesel mixt. ('green diesel') on engine emissions is similar to the impact cetane enhancement via a nitrate additive has when added to conventional diesel fuel. Advantages of hydroprocessing over esterification in the Canadian context include lower processing cost, compatibility with infrastructure, engines and fuel stds., and feed stock flexibility. Further research in the areas of process optimization, alternative feed stack selection, cold flow properties, and multi-cylinder emission testing is planned. In cooperation with a commercialization partner, Arbokem Inc., pilot testing of the hydroprocess was done and was proven successful. A fleet demonstration and evaluation is currently underway.

Renewable green diesel-type alkanes can be produced by hydrotreating jatropha oil and vegetable oils at std. hydrotreating conditions (i.e., 543-573 K) with Pt/H-ZSM-5 catalysts, which are active under the wt. ratio of jatropha or vegetable oil/catalyst of 1. The carbon molar yield of straight chain C15-C18 alkanes was ∼80% for hydrotreating pure jatropha oil. However, under the jatropha oil/catalyst wt. ratio of 10, being important from a practical point of view, the alkanes yield falls to only 2.3%. Under a high jatropha oil/catalyst ratio of 10, rhenium-modified Pt/H-ZSM-5 catalyst is found to be effective for raising the C15-C18 alkanes yield. The yield of C15-C18 alkanes is 67% at an optimum Re/Al molar ratio of 0.8. Investigation of catalyst natures indicates that metallic Pt and Re are independently present on the surface, but synergism of these two metals could play an important role in the hydrotreating reaction, even at a high ratio of jatropha oil/catalyst of 10. The reaction pathway involves hydrogenation of the C=C bonds of the jatropha oils followed by mainly hydrodeoxygenation with decarbonylation and decarboxylation to form C15-C18 straight chain alkane mixts.

A review. Microalgae are high potential raw biomass material for triglyceride feedstock, due to their high oil content and rapid growth rate, and because algae cultivation does not compete with edible food on arable land. This review addresses first the microalgae cultivation with an overview of the productivity and growth of microalgae, the recovery of lipids from the microalgae, and chem. compns. of microalgae biomass and microalgal oil. Second, three basic approaches are discussed to downstream processing for the prodn. of green gasoline and diesel hydrocarbons from microalgae oil, including cracking with zeolite, hydrotreating with supported sulfided catalysts and hydrodeoxygenation with non-sulfide metal catalysts. For the triglyceride derived bio-fuels, only "drop-in" gasoline and diesel range components are discussed in this review.

A review. The catalytic upgrading of vegetable oil to green diesel is one of the distinct research subjects in biorefineries. The catalytic conversion of triglycerides entails the method of hydrotreating such as hydrogenation, hydrodeoxygenation, decarboxylation and decarbonylation as well as isomerization. The product derived is renewable green diesel (straight chain hydrocarbon), of which its prodn. addresses the sustainability of the future energy. The main challenges faced by hydrodeoxygenation are the selection and synthesis of suitable catalysts, selection of appropriate feedstocks, optimization of the thermodn. parameters, and the reaction pathways. The literature on the selection of feedstock and model compds. is discussed in the sub-section. This review also includes the evaluation on several potential catalysts such as bimetallic solid acid, sulfided, non-sulfided, nitrides, phosphided, isomerization and hydrocracking catalysts as well as the noble metal catalysts. The selection of the metal supports catalysts, the catalyst designed practice and the overall performance is also reviewed and discussed. The most common supports used for the hydrodeoxygenation is solid acid composites such as Al2O3 and zeolites. In addn., the promoters tested yield different results with different reaction mechanisms demonstrated. The research on the hydrodeoxygenation pathways and the product distribution related with all kinds of catalysts are also addressed. In addn., the advancement of co-hydroprocessing of mix-vegetable oil and vacuumed gas oil is addressed and summarized as well. Overall, this review provides a comprehensive discussion on the hydrodeoxygenation issues and challenges in all relevant tech. aspects.

Various parameters in the catalytic hydroconversion of triglycerides (palm oil) were carefully investigated for maximizing the prodn. of biojet fuel. The results showed that the deoxygenation of triglyceride via hydrotreatment should be carried out in a sep. reactor prior to the hydrocracking step (i.e., two-step reaction process). Otherwise, the CO generated during deoxygenation can poison the metal components in the metal/acid bifunctional catalysts (Pt/zeolites), which can cause significant imbalance between the metal and acid functions in hydrocracking. This leads to fast catalyst deactivation via coke formation, heavy formation of aroms., and overcracking of hydrocarbons, resulting in the redn. of final biojet fuel yield. In the two-step process, the second hydrocracking step mainly dets. the final biojet fuel yield, and thus, a rational design of the hydrocracking catalysts that can suppress overcracking is essential. The diffusion characteristics of the multibranched hydrocarbon (e.g., 2,2,4-trimethylpentane) in the hydrocracking catalysts could be correlated with the yields of the jet fuel-range C8-C16 hydrocarbons and the iso/n-paraffin ratios. The result indicates that the facile diffusion of multibranched isomers out of catalysts before excessive cracking is important for the suppression of the formation of light hydrocarbons (≤C7). Consequently, Pt supported on nanocryst. large-pore BEA zeolite showed the largest biojet fuel yield with the highest iso-paraffin content. Under the optimized conditions, 55 wt % of biojet fuel with respect to palm oil was achieved after final distn., which satisfied all the required fuel specifications.

In this work we explore the concept of integrated biorefineries, and we examine alternative schemes for the co-prodn. of biofuels (biodiesel) and chems. (succinic acid). Four different biorefinery schemes considering the different uses of crude glycerin from the biodiesel process are simulated and compared: (i) the disposal of crude glycerin as a waste, (ii) the purifn. (through distn.) of crude glycerin to 80%, (iii) the purifn. of glycerin to 95%. and (iv) the prodn. of succinic acid from glycerin through fermn. For the latter, we consider the bioprocess that converts the glycerol to succinate, and a downstream sepn. process that purifies and crystallizes our product to the final succinic acid crystals. To apply complex kinetics for the fermn. we have linked Aspen Plus with Matlab, where we have used the exptl.-based unstructured model from Vlysidis et al., 2009 and 2010. We first det. the operating parameters of the fermentor that have a significant effect on the economics of this scenario, i.e. the cycle time of the batch fermn. and the water flowrate entering the bioreactor. Subsequently, we perform single- and multi-objective optimization to maximize the profit and/or to minimize the environmental impact of the overall process. We then analyze and compare the economics of the four different biorefinery schemes by using well-known profitability and/or emission criteria. Furthermore, we carry out sensitivity anal. that takes into consideration price variations for the most important materials and we ext. firm conclusions about the profitability of each scenario. It is found that succinic acid co-prodn. can enhance the profit of the overall biorefinery by 60% for a 20 years plant lifetime. These results indicate the importance of glycerol when it is utilized as a key renewable building block for the prodn. of commodity chems.

Although vegetable-based lubricating oils are much more biodegradable than petroleum-based lubricating oils, they are inferior in many other tech. characteristics. For vegetable-based lubricants, oxidative stability and low-temp. problems are the most crit. Thin film oxidn. test was used to compare the oxidative stabilities of vegetable oils, esp. soybean oil and high-oleic sunflower oil. Vegetable oils appear an order of magnitude less stable than mineral oils or synthetic biodegradable basestocks, such as isoalkyl adipates or poly(α-olefins). Low-temp. performance of vegetable oils, namely pour points and cold storage, was also problematic. These problems can only partially be relieved by lubricant additives; thus, vegetable oils have to be modified chem. to eliminate sites susceptible to oxidn. and to disrupt formation of crystals at low temps.

A review. Vegetable oils are being investigated as a potential source of environmentally favorable lubricants, due to a combination of biodegradability, renewability and excellent lubrication performance. Low oxidn. and thermal stability, poor low-temp. properties and narrow range of available viscosities, however, limit their potential application as industrial lubricants. This review addresses oxidn. as a limitation of vegetable oil-based lubricants. The basic mechanism of vegetable oil autoxidn. is presented, along with methods used to monitor and analyze the products of oxidn. The potential impact of such oxidn. products on lubrication performance is discussed. A brief discussion of methods used to assess and improve oxidn. stability completes the review.

Finiteness of global crude oil reserve, rising crude oil prices, and issues related to environment seems to be a reality check for the problems of emerging generations. Present article focuses on lubricating oils as well as lubricating greases developed from vegetable oil. Vegetable oil based lubricants are an attractive alternative to conventional petro based lubricants due to no. of their phys. properties including renewability, biodegradability, high lubricity and high flash points. Still they have not yet replaced petro based lubricants due to their inappropriate chem. structure, which lags them behind at various odd conditions during applications. The challenges in this field are to improve certain characteristics of vegetable oils without impairing their excellent tribol. and environmentally relevant properties. Chem. modification of vegetable oils overcomes the structural problems related to vegetable oils which in turn makes them fit for the application of lubricant. In this review article, we have reviewed the available literature and recently published data related to development of bio-lubricants by chem. modifications of vegetable oils.

Ketonization of fatty acids into fatty ketones is a potential route for producing high-value chems. including bioderived lube base oil. In the present work, the catalytic selectivity and deactivation during the ketonization of C18 fatty acids having different unsatn. degrees over a TiO2 catalyst were rigorously investigated. The results demonstrated that the yield of fatty ketone gradually decreased with increasing unsatn. degree, while byproducts such as Me ketones and olefins were produced owing to McLafferty rearrangement. It was verified that carboxylic acids longer than C5 can be decompd. via this pathway, the rate of which increased with the carbon chain length. In the ketonization of unsatd. fatty acids, the McLafferty rearrangement and cracking produced conjugated polyunsatd. olefins (e.g., dienes), which could be readily decompd. to coke. The results implied that the ketonization of natural fatty acids requires the presatn. of C=C bonds for increasing the fatty ketone yield and inhibiting catalyst deactivation. Indeed, the ketonization of a natural fatty acid mixt. obtained by palm oil hydrolysis exhibited diminished fatty ketone selectivity and rapid catalyst deactivation, owing to the presence of unsatd. fatty acids. In contrast, the ketonization of a satd. fatty acid mixt. obtained by hydrogenative hydrolysis exhibited a high fatty ketone yield (∼90%) and negligible deactivation.

Deoxygenation of triglycerides (e.g., vegetable and microalgae oils) through hydro-upgrading is one of the most important routes to produce oxygen-free hydrocarbon fuels from biomass. Even though natural triglycerides are composed of fatty acids of different structures, their effects on catalytic selectivity and deactivation during deoxygenation have not been comprehensively investigated. In this study, we used three different reactant triglycerides including palm oil, soybean oil, and linseed oil for catalytic deoxygenation over Pt/γ-Al2O3. These oils consist of fatty acids with increasing degrees of unsatn. in the order of palm oil (no. of C=C per fatty acid: 0.55) < soybean oil (1.33) < linseed oil (2.18). The catalytic results showed that the increased unsatn. of the triglycerides caused enhanced formation of heavy products by oligomerization (mostly dimers) of unsatd. fatty acid derivs. through Diels-Alder reaction and/or radical addn. These heavy products were readily transformed to coke species, causing catalyst deactivation. We demonstrated that the prehydrogenation of triglycerides at a mild temp. is highly beneficial for steadily obtaining a high yield of diesel-range paraffins and retarding catalyst deactivation in deoxygenation.

Me esters were produced by transesterification of palm oil with methanol in the presence of a catalyst (KOH). The rate of transesterification in a batch reactor increased with temp. up to 60°C. Higher temps. did not reduce the time to reach maximal conversion. The conversion of triglycerides (TG), diglycerides (DG), and monoglycerides (MG) appeared to be second order up to 30 min of reaction time. Reaction rate consts. for TG, DG, and MG hydrolysis reactions were 0.018-0.191 (wt.%-min)-1, and were higher at higher temps. and higher for the MG reaction than for TG hydrolysis. Activation energies were 14.7, 14.2, and 6.4 kcal/mol for the TG, DG, and MG hydrolysis reactions, resp. The optimal catalyst concn. was 1% KOH.

Various supported metal catalysts are screened for hydrogenation of lauric acid and 2-octanone as model reactions for the transformation of biomass-derived oxygenates to liq. alkanes (biofuels) in a batch reactor under solvent-free conditions. Among the catalysts tested, Pt and MoOx co-loaded on TiO2 (Pt-MoOx/TiO2) shows the highest yields of n-alkanes for both of the reactions. Pt-MoOx/TiO2 selectively catalyzes the hydrodeoxygenation of various fatty acids and triglycerides to n-alkanes without C-C bond cleavage under 50 bar H2 and shows higher turnover nos. than the catalysts in the literature. Pt-MoOx/TiO2 is effective also for the hydrodeoxygenation of various ketones to the corresponding alkanes. In situ IR study of the reaction of adsorbed acetone under H2 suggests that the high activity of Pt-MoOx/TiO2 is attributed to the cooperation between Pt and Lewis acid sites of the MoOx/TiO2 support.

Choi, Minkee; Wu, Zhijie; Iglesia, Enrique

The authors report here a general synthetic strategy to encapsulate metal clusters within zeolites during their hydrothermal crystn. Precursors to metal clusters are stabilized against their premature colloidal pptn. as hydroxides during zeolite crystn. using bifunctional (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane ligands. Mercapto (-SH) groups in these ligands interact with cationic metal centers, while alkoxysilane moieties form covalent Si-O-Si or Si-O-Al linkages that promote zeolite nucleation around ligated metal precursors. These protocols led to the successful encapsulation of Pt, Pd, Ir, Rh, and Ag clusters within the NaA zeolite, for which small channel apertures (0.41 nm) preclude post-synthesis deposition of metal clusters. Sequential treatments in O2 and H2 formed small (∼1 nm) clusters with uniform diam. Titrn. of exposed atoms with H2 or O2 gave metal dispersions that agree well with mean cluster sizes measured from electron microscopy and x-ray absorption spectroscopy, consistent with accessible cluster surfaces free of mercaptosilane residues. NaA micropore apertures restrict access to encapsulated clusters by reactants based on their mol. size. The ratio of the rates of hydrogenation of ethene and isobutene is much higher on clusters encapsulated within NaA than those dispersed on SiO2, as also found for the relative rates of MeOH and isobutanol oxidn. These data confirm the high encapsulation selectivity achieved by these synthetic protocols and the ability of NaA micropores to sieve reactants based on mol. size. Containment within small micropores also protects clusters against thermal sintering and prevents poisoning of active sites by organosulfur species, thus allowing alkene hydrogenation to persist even in the presence of thiophene. The bifunctional nature and remarkable specificity of the mercapto and alkoxysilane functions for metal and zeolite precursors, resp., render these protocols extendable to diverse metal-zeolite systems useful as shape-selective catalysts in demanding chem. environments.

A new calcn. method for the detn. of iodine value (IV) from measurements of fatty acid Me esters is proposed. The method is based on the quant. detn. of fatty acid Me esters of vegetable oils by capillary gas chromatog. IV is a measure of the no. of double bonds in the unsatd. fatty acids in one gram of oil. The anal. methodol. of its evaluation includes the use of dangerous reagents, and for that reason is mostly avoided by lab. analysts. A calcn. procedure to det. the IV of oils from their fatty acid Me ester compn. is in use based on the American Oil Chemists' Society (AOCS) method Cd 1c-85. A new calcn. procedure for IV, based also on the evaluation of the fatty acid Me esters of oils, was developed. The application of the proposed calcn. methodol. was checked with olive oil, corn oil, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, and sunflower seed oil. The proposed calcn. gave results in better agreement with the Wijs method than with the relevant AOCS method.

Several theories have been proposed concerning the stand oil reaction but no precise reaction scheme has been described. In this work, the stand reaction of linseed oil was characterized in order to det. the nature of the products formed during this reaction. Using complementary anal. techniques (more esp. NMR and mass spectrometry), the existence of two different reactions was demonstrated: the Diels-Alder addn. between fatty acid chains and the addn. of a methylene radical on double bonds, followed by combination or elimination reactions.

By employing spectroscopic methods for estn. of conjugated and nonconjugated polyene adds and new methods for detg. mono-, di-, and trimeric Me esters, a detailed kinetic study was made of the thermal polymerization of pure Me linoleate and its isomers. Isomerization (KOH-glycol at 180°) was used to det. nonconjugated esters and the method of Cowan, Falkenburg, and Teeter (C.A. 38, 1891.9) was used for detg. mono-, di-, and trimeric esters. Materials studied included normal Me linoleate, Me linolelaidate, cis, trans-Me linoleate, the Me ester of alkali-conjugated linoleic acid, and Me 10, 12-linoleate. Details are given for the prepn. of some of these materials. Rate consts. for the disappearance of nonconjugated linoleate were calcd. from analysis by means of 6-hr. isomerization of samples taken at intervals during thermal polymerization. It was found that the various linoleates differed in speed of reaction and in ratio of dimer to trimer. Differences in speeds of reaction are believed to be related to the geometry of the various isomers. Qual. explanations of the differences in dimer to trimer ratios are made on the assumption that the trimer results from a Diels-Alder or other type of addn. of an isolated double bond in a dimer with a conjugated diene.

cf. CA 54, 20439b. The pyrolysis of 1-butene (I) contg. 5% by vol. biallyl (II) at 506°/200 mm. produced (I by itself gave no reaction): H, CH4, C2H6, C2H4, propene, cyclopentadiene, cyclopentene, methylcyclopentene, cyclohexene, benzene, and methylcyclohexene. The concn. of each of the principal products was linear with respect to the square root of the concn. of II, confirming that the initial step was the splitting of II into 2 allyl radicals. These radicals then either abstracted H from I (to form propene and butenyl radical) or added to the double bond in I (to form heptenyl radical), in either case splitting off cyclic and linear products. The pyrolysis of ethene-II mixts. 5 min. at 506°/200 mm. produced (ethene by itself did not react) (in a typical run, with 6.7% II): H, 0.47; CH4, 0.50; C2H6, 1.3; C2H4, 89; propene, 3.7; I, 1.0; cyclopentene, 2.5; 1,4-pentadiene, 1.3; II, 0.07 mole-%. The concn. of propene, the principal product, was linear with respect to the square root of the concn. of II. The most probable reaction was the addn. of allyl radical to the double bond of C2H4 to form the pentenyl radical. The similar pyrolysis of propene (no reaction in the absence of II) contg. 5.3% II yielded (5 min. at 506°/200 mm.): H, 0.37; CH4, 1.17; C2H6, 0.16; C2H4, 2.29; propane, 0.73; propene, 92.0; I, 1.11; cyclopentene, 0.94; 1-hexene, 0.94; methylcyclopentene, 0.28; II, 0.50 mole-%. The double bond addn. of the allyl radical to form the hexenyl radical was the important reaction leading to the products although part of the yield could be accounted for by the decompn. of II itself. The pyrolysis of n-butane alone (5 min. at 506°/200 mm.) produced: CH4, 2.0; C2H6, 0.9; C2H4, 0.9; I, negligible mole-%. The same reaction with 5% II present produced: CH4, 4.9; C2H6, 2.0; C2H4, 3.4; I, 1.7; 1-pentene, 0.85; benzene, negligible mole-%. The principle reaction probably was abstraction by allyl radical of H from butane (to form propene and Me radicals and C2H4 and Et radicals). The residual reactions in hydrocarbon decompn. that were found to be fully inhibited by propene were probably processes in which chains were propagated by less effective (more stable) radicals such as allyl, the highly reactive alkyl radicals being reduced in concn. by reaction with propene. The inhibition by NO (12 times that by propene) was attributed to the alkyl radical removal process.

Thermally induced reactions occurring in lipids under nonoxidative conditions are reviewed. Free fatty acids may be formed in the absence or presence of moisture. In thermal hydrolysis of triglycerides there is a preferential release of the shorter-chain and the unsatd. fatty acids, but no positional specificity is observed. The mechanisms of formation of lactones, methyl ketones, hydrocarbons, and monocarboxylic and dicarboxylic methyl esters in heated fats are discussed.

Advances in genetics, biotechnol., process chem., and engineering are leading to a new manufg. concept for converting renewable biomass to valuable fuels and products, generally referred to as the biorefinery. The integration of agro-energy crops and biorefinery manufg. technologies offers the potential for the development of sustainable bio-power and biomaterials that will lead to a new manufg. paradigm.

A review. This article is an up-to-date review of the literature available on the subject of liq. biofuels. In search of a suitable fuel alternative to fast depleting fossil fuel and oil reserves and in serious consideration of the environmental issues assocd. with the extensive use of fuels based on petrochems., research work is in progress worldwide. Researchers have been re-directing their interests in biomass based fuels, which currently seem to be the only logical alternative for sustainable development in the context of economical and environmental considerations. Renewable bioresources are available globally in the form of residual agricultural biomass and wastes, which can be transformed into liq. biofuels. However, the process of conversion, or chem. transformation, could be very expensive and not worth-while to use for an economical large-scale com. supply of biofuels. Hence, there is still need for much research to be done for an effective, economical and efficient conversion process. Therefore, this article is written as a broad overview of the subject, and includes information based on the research conducted globally by scientists according to their local socio-cultural and economic situations.

A review with 38 refs. Diesel fuels derived from triglycerides (vegetable oils/animal fats) present a promising alternative to substitute diesel fuels. Although triglycerides can fuel diesel engines, their high viscosities, low volatilities and poor cold flow properties have led to the investigation of various derivs. Fatty acid Me esters, known as biodiesel, derived from triglycerides by transesterification with methanol have received the most attention. The main advantages of using biodiesel are its renewability, better-quality exhaust gas emissions, its biodegradability and given that all the org. carbon present is photosynthetic in origin, it does not contribute to a rise in the level of carbon dioxide in the atm. and consequently to the greenhouse effect.

A review. Biodiesel is gaining more and more importance as an attractive fuel due to the depleting fossil fuel resources. Chem. biodiesel is monoalkyl esters of long chain fatty acids derived from renewable feed stock like vegetable oils and animal fats. It is produced by transesterification in which, oil or fat is reacted with a monohydric alc. in presence of a catalyst. The process of transesterification is affected by the mode of reaction condition, molar ratio of alc. to oil, type of alc., type and amt. of catalysts, reaction time and temp. and purity of reactants. In the present paper various methods of prepn. of biodiesel with different combination of oil and catalysts have been described. The tech. tools and processes for monitoring the transesterification reactions like TLC, GC, HPLC, GPC, 1H NMR and NIR have also been summarized. In addn., fuel properties and specifications provided by different countries are discussed.

A review. The search for alternatives to petroleum-based fuels has led to the development of fuels from various sources, including renewable feedstocks such as fats and oils. Several types of fuels can be derived from these triacylglycerol-contg. feedstocks. One of them is biodiesel, which is defined as the mono-alkyl esters of vegetable oils or animal fats. Biodiesel is produced by transesterifying the oil or fat with an alc. such as methanol under mild conditions in the presence of a base catalyst. Another kind of product that can be obtained from lipid feedstocks is a fuel whose compn. simulates that of petroleum-derived diesel fuel. This kind of fuel, probably best termed "renewable diesel", is produced from the fat or oil by a hydrodeoxygenation reaction at elevated temp. and pressure in the presence of a catalyst. This article discusses in a general and comparative fashion aspects such as fuel prodn. and energy balance, fuel properties, environmental effects including exhaust emissions and co-products. Among the questions that are addressed are if these fuels compete with or complement each other and what the effect of prodn. scale may be.

Microalgae oil can be nearly quant. hydrodeoxygenated to alkanes by cascade reactions on bifunctional catalysts based on Ni and an acidic zeolite. Ni catalyzes the hydrogenolysis of the fatty acid ester, the decarbonylation of aldehyde intermediates, as well as the hydrogenation of -COOH, -CHO and C=C double bonds in reactants and intermediates. The acid function catalyzes the dehydration of alc. intermediates and the hydroisomerization and hydrocracking of the alkane products. The knowledge of the individual reaction rates allows balancing these rates by adjusting the concn. of catalytically active sites to design tailored and stable catalysts for selectively converting crude microalgae oil to diesel-range alkanes. This approach opens new possibilities to produce sulfur-free high-grade green transportation fuels from microalgae on a large scale.

The Saskatchewan Research Council (SRC), in cooperation with Natural Resources Canada and Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, investigated the use of conventional refinery technol. to convert vegetable oils into a product resembling diesel fuel. SRC found that the use of a medium severity refinery hydroprocess yielded a product ('super cetane') in the diesel boiling range with a high cetane value (55-90). Preliminary engine testing by ORTECH has shown that the impact of the 'super cetane'/diesel mixt. ('green diesel') on engine emissions is similar to the impact cetane enhancement via a nitrate additive has when added to conventional diesel fuel. Advantages of hydroprocessing over esterification in the Canadian context include lower processing cost, compatibility with infrastructure, engines and fuel stds., and feed stock flexibility. Further research in the areas of process optimization, alternative feed stack selection, cold flow properties, and multi-cylinder emission testing is planned. In cooperation with a commercialization partner, Arbokem Inc., pilot testing of the hydroprocess was done and was proven successful. A fleet demonstration and evaluation is currently underway.

Renewable green diesel-type alkanes can be produced by hydrotreating jatropha oil and vegetable oils at std. hydrotreating conditions (i.e., 543-573 K) with Pt/H-ZSM-5 catalysts, which are active under the wt. ratio of jatropha or vegetable oil/catalyst of 1. The carbon molar yield of straight chain C15-C18 alkanes was ∼80% for hydrotreating pure jatropha oil. However, under the jatropha oil/catalyst wt. ratio of 10, being important from a practical point of view, the alkanes yield falls to only 2.3%. Under a high jatropha oil/catalyst ratio of 10, rhenium-modified Pt/H-ZSM-5 catalyst is found to be effective for raising the C15-C18 alkanes yield. The yield of C15-C18 alkanes is 67% at an optimum Re/Al molar ratio of 0.8. Investigation of catalyst natures indicates that metallic Pt and Re are independently present on the surface, but synergism of these two metals could play an important role in the hydrotreating reaction, even at a high ratio of jatropha oil/catalyst of 10. The reaction pathway involves hydrogenation of the C=C bonds of the jatropha oils followed by mainly hydrodeoxygenation with decarbonylation and decarboxylation to form C15-C18 straight chain alkane mixts.

A review. Microalgae are high potential raw biomass material for triglyceride feedstock, due to their high oil content and rapid growth rate, and because algae cultivation does not compete with edible food on arable land. This review addresses first the microalgae cultivation with an overview of the productivity and growth of microalgae, the recovery of lipids from the microalgae, and chem. compns. of microalgae biomass and microalgal oil. Second, three basic approaches are discussed to downstream processing for the prodn. of green gasoline and diesel hydrocarbons from microalgae oil, including cracking with zeolite, hydrotreating with supported sulfided catalysts and hydrodeoxygenation with non-sulfide metal catalysts. For the triglyceride derived bio-fuels, only "drop-in" gasoline and diesel range components are discussed in this review.

A review. The catalytic upgrading of vegetable oil to green diesel is one of the distinct research subjects in biorefineries. The catalytic conversion of triglycerides entails the method of hydrotreating such as hydrogenation, hydrodeoxygenation, decarboxylation and decarbonylation as well as isomerization. The product derived is renewable green diesel (straight chain hydrocarbon), of which its prodn. addresses the sustainability of the future energy. The main challenges faced by hydrodeoxygenation are the selection and synthesis of suitable catalysts, selection of appropriate feedstocks, optimization of the thermodn. parameters, and the reaction pathways. The literature on the selection of feedstock and model compds. is discussed in the sub-section. This review also includes the evaluation on several potential catalysts such as bimetallic solid acid, sulfided, non-sulfided, nitrides, phosphided, isomerization and hydrocracking catalysts as well as the noble metal catalysts. The selection of the metal supports catalysts, the catalyst designed practice and the overall performance is also reviewed and discussed. The most common supports used for the hydrodeoxygenation is solid acid composites such as Al2O3 and zeolites. In addn., the promoters tested yield different results with different reaction mechanisms demonstrated. The research on the hydrodeoxygenation pathways and the product distribution related with all kinds of catalysts are also addressed. In addn., the advancement of co-hydroprocessing of mix-vegetable oil and vacuumed gas oil is addressed and summarized as well. Overall, this review provides a comprehensive discussion on the hydrodeoxygenation issues and challenges in all relevant tech. aspects.

Kim, Myoung Yeob; Kim, Jae-Kon; Lee, Mi-Eun; Lee, Songhyun; Choi, Minkee

Various parameters in the catalytic hydroconversion of triglycerides (palm oil) were carefully investigated for maximizing the prodn. of biojet fuel. The results showed that the deoxygenation of triglyceride via hydrotreatment should be carried out in a sep. reactor prior to the hydrocracking step (i.e., two-step reaction process). Otherwise, the CO generated during deoxygenation can poison the metal components in the metal/acid bifunctional catalysts (Pt/zeolites), which can cause significant imbalance between the metal and acid functions in hydrocracking. This leads to fast catalyst deactivation via coke formation, heavy formation of aroms., and overcracking of hydrocarbons, resulting in the redn. of final biojet fuel yield. In the two-step process, the second hydrocracking step mainly dets. the final biojet fuel yield, and thus, a rational design of the hydrocracking catalysts that can suppress overcracking is essential. The diffusion characteristics of the multibranched hydrocarbon (e.g., 2,2,4-trimethylpentane) in the hydrocracking catalysts could be correlated with the yields of the jet fuel-range C8-C16 hydrocarbons and the iso/n-paraffin ratios. The result indicates that the facile diffusion of multibranched isomers out of catalysts before excessive cracking is important for the suppression of the formation of light hydrocarbons (≤C7). Consequently, Pt supported on nanocryst. large-pore BEA zeolite showed the largest biojet fuel yield with the highest iso-paraffin content. Under the optimized conditions, 55 wt % of biojet fuel with respect to palm oil was achieved after final distn., which satisfied all the required fuel specifications.

In this work we explore the concept of integrated biorefineries, and we examine alternative schemes for the co-prodn. of biofuels (biodiesel) and chems. (succinic acid). Four different biorefinery schemes considering the different uses of crude glycerin from the biodiesel process are simulated and compared: (i) the disposal of crude glycerin as a waste, (ii) the purifn. (through distn.) of crude glycerin to 80%, (iii) the purifn. of glycerin to 95%. and (iv) the prodn. of succinic acid from glycerin through fermn. For the latter, we consider the bioprocess that converts the glycerol to succinate, and a downstream sepn. process that purifies and crystallizes our product to the final succinic acid crystals. To apply complex kinetics for the fermn. we have linked Aspen Plus with Matlab, where we have used the exptl.-based unstructured model from Vlysidis et al., 2009 and 2010. We first det. the operating parameters of the fermentor that have a significant effect on the economics of this scenario, i.e. the cycle time of the batch fermn. and the water flowrate entering the bioreactor. Subsequently, we perform single- and multi-objective optimization to maximize the profit and/or to minimize the environmental impact of the overall process. We then analyze and compare the economics of the four different biorefinery schemes by using well-known profitability and/or emission criteria. Furthermore, we carry out sensitivity anal. that takes into consideration price variations for the most important materials and we ext. firm conclusions about the profitability of each scenario. It is found that succinic acid co-prodn. can enhance the profit of the overall biorefinery by 60% for a 20 years plant lifetime. These results indicate the importance of glycerol when it is utilized as a key renewable building block for the prodn. of commodity chems.

Although vegetable-based lubricating oils are much more biodegradable than petroleum-based lubricating oils, they are inferior in many other tech. characteristics. For vegetable-based lubricants, oxidative stability and low-temp. problems are the most crit. Thin film oxidn. test was used to compare the oxidative stabilities of vegetable oils, esp. soybean oil and high-oleic sunflower oil. Vegetable oils appear an order of magnitude less stable than mineral oils or synthetic biodegradable basestocks, such as isoalkyl adipates or poly(α-olefins). Low-temp. performance of vegetable oils, namely pour points and cold storage, was also problematic. These problems can only partially be relieved by lubricant additives; thus, vegetable oils have to be modified chem. to eliminate sites susceptible to oxidn. and to disrupt formation of crystals at low temps.

A review. Vegetable oils are being investigated as a potential source of environmentally favorable lubricants, due to a combination of biodegradability, renewability and excellent lubrication performance. Low oxidn. and thermal stability, poor low-temp. properties and narrow range of available viscosities, however, limit their potential application as industrial lubricants. This review addresses oxidn. as a limitation of vegetable oil-based lubricants. The basic mechanism of vegetable oil autoxidn. is presented, along with methods used to monitor and analyze the products of oxidn. The potential impact of such oxidn. products on lubrication performance is discussed. A brief discussion of methods used to assess and improve oxidn. stability completes the review.

Finiteness of global crude oil reserve, rising crude oil prices, and issues related to environment seems to be a reality check for the problems of emerging generations. Present article focuses on lubricating oils as well as lubricating greases developed from vegetable oil. Vegetable oil based lubricants are an attractive alternative to conventional petro based lubricants due to no. of their phys. properties including renewability, biodegradability, high lubricity and high flash points. Still they have not yet replaced petro based lubricants due to their inappropriate chem. structure, which lags them behind at various odd conditions during applications. The challenges in this field are to improve certain characteristics of vegetable oils without impairing their excellent tribol. and environmentally relevant properties. Chem. modification of vegetable oils overcomes the structural problems related to vegetable oils which in turn makes them fit for the application of lubricant. In this review article, we have reviewed the available literature and recently published data related to development of bio-lubricants by chem. modifications of vegetable oils.

Long-chain alkanes that can be used as alternative premium diesel fuel or lubricating base oils can be obtained by a four-step process in a single reactor with two catalyst beds. First, two fatty acid mols. are coupled by ketonic decarboxylation over MgO. The carbonyl product is then hydrogenated, and after the elimination of water, the resulting olefin is further hydrogenated to produce the alkane in up to 58% yield (using Pt/MgO catalyst).

Ketonization of fatty acids into fatty ketones is a potential route for producing high-value chems. including bioderived lube base oil. In the present work, the catalytic selectivity and deactivation during the ketonization of C18 fatty acids having different unsatn. degrees over a TiO2 catalyst were rigorously investigated. The results demonstrated that the yield of fatty ketone gradually decreased with increasing unsatn. degree, while byproducts such as Me ketones and olefins were produced owing to McLafferty rearrangement. It was verified that carboxylic acids longer than C5 can be decompd. via this pathway, the rate of which increased with the carbon chain length. In the ketonization of unsatd. fatty acids, the McLafferty rearrangement and cracking produced conjugated polyunsatd. olefins (e.g., dienes), which could be readily decompd. to coke. The results implied that the ketonization of natural fatty acids requires the presatn. of C=C bonds for increasing the fatty ketone yield and inhibiting catalyst deactivation. Indeed, the ketonization of a natural fatty acid mixt. obtained by palm oil hydrolysis exhibited diminished fatty ketone selectivity and rapid catalyst deactivation, owing to the presence of unsatd. fatty acids. In contrast, the ketonization of a satd. fatty acid mixt. obtained by hydrogenative hydrolysis exhibited a high fatty ketone yield (∼90%) and negligible deactivation.
